entry.title: Winifred Brown (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that when Winifred Brown (pictured) arrived for the King's Cup air race in 1930, she was not allowed to stay at the aero club but still won the race?

entry.title: first Eurovision Song Contest (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that voting in the first Eurovision Song Contest was conducted in secret, with countries able to vote for their own entries, and only the winner of the contest being announced?

entry.title: William White (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that William White's last NFL game was Super Bowl XXXIII, in which he made a team-high nine tackles for the losing Atlanta Falcons?

entry.title: Leafpad (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Leafpad is a text editor for Linux that is comparable to Notepad for Windows?

entry.title: Balanda Atis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that cosmetic chemist Balanda Atis created the foundation worn by Lupita Nyong'o in advertisements for Lancôme?

entry.title: jieba (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a practice known as jieba, in which a Buddhist monk has scars ritually burned into his head, was banned by the Chinese government for 300 years?

entry.title: Clifford G. Grulee (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Clifford G. Grulee died while attending a dinner hosted by the American Academy of Pediatrics in his honor?

entry.title: International Institute of Modern Letters (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the name of the International Institute of Modern Letters has been criticised by its founder Bill Manhire for being "almost at odds with the fine use of language"?
